Type 2 diabetes is the most common type of diabetes and is characterized by insulin resistance. The insulin is ineffective in the body, resulting in rising blood sugar levels. To lower these blood sugar levels, the pancreas produces more insulin. Over time, this can exhaust the pancreas resulting in less insulin production and rising blood sugar levels.\n Insulin, a hormone produced by the pancreas, is essential for the processing of glucose from food in the body. Carbohydrates in food are broken down into glucose in the stomach and intestines. Glucose is then by cells in the intestines and released into the bloodstream to be transported throughout the body. Glucose is used for energy production in cells.\n However, glucose is unable to pass through the cell membrane of most cells. Insulin stimulates the uptake of glucose into cells. Being unable to produce or use insulin effectively leads to increased blood sugar levels (hyperglycaemia), which can cause serious health problems.

Type 2 diabetes is caused by several factors including genetic predisposition, increasing age and modifiable lifestyle factors such as:
 - Being overweight or obese
 - Unhealthy diet
 - Physical inactivity
 - Smoking
 - Certain medicines

Type 2 diabetes patients have an increased risk of developing serious diseases including:
 - Cardiovascular disease
 - Kidney damage
 - Nerve damage
 - Eye damage
 - Slow healing wounds
 - Alzheimer's disease

In nearly all high-income countries, diabetes is the primary cause of blindness, cardiovascular disease, lower limb amputation and kidney failure.

Type 2 diabetes can be managed through lifestyle modification including regular exercise, a healthy diet, maintaining a healthy body weight and smoking cessation. However, type 2 diabetes is a progressive disease, which means that the pancreas may not be able to produce enough insulin to keep the blood sugar level within the target range, regardless of the lifestyle modification. People with type 2 diabetes should then take oral medication to keep the blood sugar level within the target range. If this is still not sufficient, insulin injections may be necessary. The injections and oral medication are intended to be used in combination with regular exercise and healthy eating, not as a substitute.
